segment.target: Asynchronous loading is handled using the task template from the Parallel Patterns Library (PPL).

segment.source: Tasks can be chained together using the .then() syntax, so that when one operation completes, another async operation that depends on the results of the prior operation can be run.

segment.source: Loading meshes
segment.target: Loading meshes

segment.source: Meshes are vertex data, either generated procedurally by code within your game or exported to a file from another app (like 3DStudio MAX or Alias WaveFront) or tool.
segment.target: Meshes are vertex data, either generated procedurally by code within your game or exported to a file from another app (like 3DStudio MAX or Alias WaveFront) or tool.

segment.source: These meshes represent the models in your game, from simple primitives like cubes and spheres to cars and houses and characters.
segment.target: These meshes represent the models in your game, from simple primitives like cubes and spheres to cars and houses and characters.

segment.source: They often contain color and animation data, as well, depending on their format.
segment.target: They often contain color and animation data, as well, depending on their format.

segment.source: We'll focus on meshes that contain only vertex data.
segment.target: We'll focus on meshes that contain only vertex data.

segment.source: To load a mesh correctly, you must know the format of the data in the file for the mesh.
segment.target: To load a mesh correctly, you must know the format of the data in the file for the mesh.

segment.source: Our simple BasicReaderWriter type above simply reads the data in as a byte stream; it doesn't know that the byte data represents a mesh, much less a specific mesh format as exported by another application!
segment.target: Our simple BasicReaderWriter type above simply reads the data in as a byte stream; it doesn't know that the byte data represents a mesh, much less a specific mesh format as exported by another application!

segment.source: You must perform the conversion as you bring the mesh data into memory.
segment.target: You must perform the conversion as you bring the mesh data into memory.

segment.source: (You should always try to package asset data in a format that's as close to the internal representation as possible.

segment.source: The layout of the vertex data in the .vbo file looks like this:
segment.target: The layout of the vertex data in the .vbo file looks like this:

segment.source: The first 32 bits (4 bytes) of the data stream contain the number of vertices (numVertices) in the mesh, represented as a uint32 value.
segment.target: The first 32 bits (4 bytes) of the data stream contain the number of vertices (numVertices) in the mesh, represented as a uint32 value.

segment.source: The next 32 bits (4 bytes) of the data stream contain the number of indices in the mesh (numIndices), represented as a uint32 value.
segment.target: The next 32 bits (4 bytes) of the data stream contain the number of indices in the mesh (numIndices), represented as a uint32 value.

segment.source: After that, the subsequent (numVertices \* sizeof(BasicVertex)) bits contain the vertex data.
segment.target: After that, the subsequent (numVertices \* sizeof(BasicVertex)) bits contain the vertex data.

segment.source: The last (numIndices \* 16) bits of data contain the index data, represented as a sequence of uint16 values.
segment.target: The last (numIndices \* 16) bits of data contain the index data, represented as a sequence of uint16 values.

segment.source: The point is this: know the bit-level layout of the mesh data you have loaded.
segment.target: The point is this: know the bit-level layout of the mesh data you have loaded.

segment.source: Also, be sure you are consistent with endian-ness.
segment.target: Also, be sure you are consistent with endian-ness.

segment.source: All Windows 8 platforms are little-endian.
segment.target: All Windows 8 platforms are little-endian.

segment.source: Loading textures
segment.target: Loading textures

segment.source: The most common asset in a game—and the one that comprises most of the files on disk and in memory—are textures.
segment.target: The most common asset in a game—and the one that comprises most of the files on disk and in memory—are textures.

segment.source: Like meshes, textures can come in a variety of formats, and you convert them to a format that Direct3D can use when you load them.
segment.target: Like meshes, textures can come in a variety of formats, and you convert them to a format that Direct3D can use when you load them.

segment.source: Textures also come in a wide variety of types and are used to create different effects.
segment.target: Textures also come in a wide variety of types and are used to create different effects.

segment.source: MIP levels for textures can be used to improve the look and performance of distance objects; dirt and light maps are used to layer effects and detail atop a base texture; and normal maps are used in per-pixel lighting calculations.
segment.target: MIP levels for textures can be used to improve the look and performance of distance objects; dirt and light maps are used to layer effects and detail atop a base texture; and normal maps are used in per-pixel lighting calculations.

segment.source: In a modern game, a typical scene can potentially have thousands of individual textures, and your code must effectively manage them all!
segment.target: In a modern game, a typical scene can potentially have thousands of individual textures, and your code must effectively manage them all!

segment.source: Also like meshes, there are a number of specific formats that are used to make memory usage for efficient.
segment.target: Also like meshes, there are a number of specific formats that are used to make memory usage for efficient.

segment.source: Since textures can easily consume a large portion of the GPU (and system) memory, they are often compressed in some fashion.
segment.target: Since textures can easily consume a large portion of the GPU (and system) memory, they are often compressed in some fashion.

segment.source: You aren't required to use compression on your game's textures, and you can use any compression/decompression algorithm(s) you want as long as you provide the Direct3D shaders with data in a format it can understand (like a Texture2D bitmap).
segment.target: You aren't required to use compression on your game's textures, and you can use any compression/decompression algorithm(s) you want as long as you provide the Direct3D shaders with data in a format it can understand (like a Texture2D bitmap).

segment.source: Direct3D provides support for the DXT texture compression algorithms, although every DXT format may not be supported in the player's graphics hardware.
segment.target: Direct3D provides support for the DXT texture compression algorithms, although every DXT format may not be supported in the player's graphics hardware.

segment.source: DDS files contain DXT textures (and other texture compression formats as well), and are suffixed with .dds.
segment.target: DDS files contain DXT textures (and other texture compression formats as well), and are suffixed with .dds.

segment.source: A DDS file is a binary file that contains the following information:
segment.target: A DDS file is a binary file that contains the following information:

segment.source: A DWORD (magic number) containing the four character code value 'DDS ' (0x20534444).
segment.target: A DWORD (magic number) containing the four character code value 'DDS ' (0x20534444).

segment.source: A description of the data in the file.
segment.target: A description of the data in the file.

segment.source: The data is described with a header description using DDS\_HEADER; the pixel format is defined using DDS\_PIXELFORMAT.
segment.target: The data is described with a header description using DDS\_HEADER; the pixel format is defined using DDS\_PIXELFORMAT.

segment.source: Note that the DDS\_HEADER and DDS\_PIXELFORMAT structures replace the deprecated DDSURFACEDESC2, DDSCAPS2 and DDPIXELFORMAT DirectDraw 7 structures.
segment.target: Note that the DDS\_HEADER and DDS\_PIXELFORMAT structures replace the deprecated DDSURFACEDESC2, DDSCAPS2 and DDPIXELFORMAT DirectDraw 7 structures.

segment.target: DDS\_HEADER is the binary equivalent of DDSURFACEDESC2 and DDSCAPS2.

segment.source: DDS\_PIXELFORMAT is the binary equivalent of DDPIXELFORMAT.
segment.target: DDS\_PIXELFORMAT is the binary equivalent of DDPIXELFORMAT.

segment.source: Shaders are compiled High Level Shader Language (HLSL) files that are loaded into memory and invoked at specific stages of the graphics pipeline.
segment.target: Shaders are compiled High Level Shader Language (HLSL) files that are loaded into memory and invoked at specific stages of the graphics pipeline.

segment.source: The most common and essential shaders are the vertex and pixel shaders, which process the individual vertices of your mesh and the pixels in the scene's viewport(s), respectively.
segment.target: The most common and essential shaders are the vertex and pixel shaders, which process the individual vertices of your mesh and the pixels in the scene's viewport(s), respectively.

segment.source: The HLSL code is executed to transform the geometry, apply lighting effects and textures, and perform post-processing on the rendered scene.
segment.target: The HLSL code is executed to transform the geometry, apply lighting effects and textures, and perform post-processing on the rendered scene.

segment.source: A Direct3D game can have a number of different shaders, each one compiled into a separate CSO (Compiled Shader Object, .cso) file.
segment.target: A Direct3D game can have a number of different shaders, each one compiled into a separate CSO (Compiled Shader Object, .cso) file.
